reviewText: I'd have to say this is probably the nicest collection of G films that is currently available.  Classic Media really outdid themselves here given the lack of care with other Godzilla releases.  The physical outer case is embarrassingly well-built and attractive.  The photos in the product description can't do it justice.  The cases for the individual films are just as aesthetically pleasing.  Unfortunately, I found these to function rather poorly (excluding the Gojira/Godzilla 2-disc set).  The spines are TOO thick/strong and prevent the front flap from staying closed on its own since there is no locking mechanism.  Opening them makes an extremely unhealthy sound of dried glue being ripped off cardboard, although no harm is ever done to the case.  It was pretty alarming the first time I opened them.  My biggest complaint with the cases are the ridiculous death grip they have on discs.  I became so fearful of disc damage that eventually I took a little nail file ever-so-slightly to the plastic tabs in order to round them off a little bit.  It did the trick but I got a little careless and rounded one off too much so now the disc easily falls out.  If these weren't in a bigger case it would be terrible to deal with these individually.  I bought my set a while ago so they may have fixed these quirks since then.  Maybe someone else can comment?But my minor gripes with the cases are by far the biggest drawback to this set.  The DVD production is really top-notch on them all.  Beautiful menus and navigation genuinely reflect the film and it's time.  The prints used for all the Japanese versions were in extremely good, clean condition.  Vibrant colors, sharp detail, etc.  A couple of the films' Americanized versions are comparatively poor being dark with considerable scratches.  I certainly wouldn't consider any of them "unwatchable."  Its my understanding that as these DVDs were being released individually Classic Media eventually started using the already-restored footage from the Japanese versions to reconstruct the English ones.  Kind of disappointing this wasn't the case for Mothra vs. Godzilla because the English dub of this film is what sparked my interest in Godzilla as a kid.  I realize that most people would rather watch the original Japanese cuts anyways.  Not really a big deal I suppose.  I also find it ironic that arguably the worst Godzilla film ever made, All Monsters Attack aka Godzilla's Revenge, is arguably the best overall quality here.  It's kind of hard to grade the audio track to films that are 35-60 years old.  None of them have a strong hiss or contain pops and crackles so I'd call them adequate.The special features are a mixed bag.  Trailers are always fun to watch and they are in decent shape.  Those classic posters are great to see too.  There is nothing real profound in the way of featurettes.  It's quite understandable considering the severe lack of media surrounding the production of these films.  I'd imagine producing a brand new full-length documentary would probably be far too costly.  Instead we get some extremely detailed commentaries by very well-informed experts.  Combining the commentaries with the featurettes gives you an excellent overview in the same way a documentary would.  In terms of the extras, Classic Media probably did the most effective job they could based on what they were given.I'd say this set is a must-have for even casual G fans.  The excellent DVD presentation more than makes up for the superficial packaging flaws.  It's not enough to justify knocking off a whole star.  I bought this nearly 2 years ago and since then the price has dropped to nearly half that.  At the current price of $19 this is a steal.***EDIT*** May 6, 2012It appears Classic Media now has a re-designed case with flimsy standard-sized DVD cases (divided in 2 volumes).  Sadly many companies are re-packaging older box sets and labeling them as "slim packaging."  In reality they should just be calling these "corner-cutting cheapie cases."  While I complained about the functionality of the first version at least it was very solid, pretty unique, and aesthetically pleasing.  These new cases appear mediocre on all levels.  However I don't see it as being a deal breaker.  The set is still a good value based on disc content alone (even with a price hike to now $25) but it loses some pizazz with this case downgrade.

reviewText: Just wanted to say if you have any thought in your mind about purchasing this, BUY IT NOW! I bought this when it was around thirty-five dollars and it was worth every penny. The main-menus are very well done and they really tried give the fans what they wanted. I'm so glad they included the Japanese uncut version with excellent special features. I hated the fact that I missed out on minutes of footage on my 15 year old VHS tapes.Godzilla King of Monsters- Godzilla doesn't fight any monsters in this one, but this film is incredible. It was the first time I saw it, which was only months ago, it went way past my expectations. It was creepy, cool and loved seeing Godzilla as the bad guy. Probably the best Godzilla storyline out of all the movies. I mean the human scenes were interesting to watch! I couldn't believe this was possible in a godzilla film. The heavily edited dubbed American version isn't horrible, but there's no positive reason to watch it, unless you hate reading subtitles. 10/10 (for original) 5/10 (for American)Godzilla Raids Again- The sequel to King of Monsters! Now this godzilla film is pretty good. Godzilla is still heel which is nice, and we get to see the first appearnce of Anguirus, which is one of my favorite monsters. The black and white film is still here keeping it more dark and evil. The human scenes are not near as good as the first one's, but I liked the military discussion scenes. The biggest problem about the film is the fight between Godzill and Angurius... it's in fast motion and it was a stupid idea for the film-makers to do this. I still like it though. The iceberg conflict, godzilla's crazy teeth and roars make this a good one. Except the American version which switches Godzilla and Angurius' roar... which detracts from the film immensely. The iceberg scenes are some of the most exciting and intense as well. 7.5/10 or 8/10 if fight scene wasn't in fast motion.Godzilla vs. Mothra- Godzilla makes an awesome entrance and is still a heel, but is shown more as a destructive force of nature, which is how it should be. The big-due breaks a lot of buildings, destroys a lot of tanks and kills Mothra. Human scenes are watchable and actually interesting. The American version actually adds a military scene where the shoot missles at Godzilla which is really awesome, which gives a slight advantage in the version to watch, but the American version does have weaker quality than Japanese version. Also, out of every Godzilla film, this has the best suit-acting in my opinion, also the first time you get to here the amazing Godzilla theme, it's very powerful and gives me goosebumps. 9.5/10Ghidorah the three-headed Monster- Really good godzilla film. Godzilla, Rodan, Mothra and King-Ghidorah cause some hell. Lot of action, in the last half anyway. Watch Japenese version, for American editing issues. Godzilla and Rodan fighting is probably the highlight of the film and it's the last time Godzilla has his smoke breath. The final battle is decent, great team-work moments. Godzilla throws a bit too many rocks though. The human scenes also get in the way of the battle sometimes. Also the Godzilla theme is also present in this one, making it even more awesome. 9/10Godzilla vs. Monster Zero- Basically, the sequel to Ghidorah!! Pretty similair to first (monsters fight ghidorah), excpet there's two excellent fight scenes that are more impressive than the first, without the addition of Mothra (thank goodness). Excellent action and fight scenes, that are very memorable. American version is fine since almost nothing is edited out. Just avoid human scenes though... they're very dull. The Godzilla suit, has an improved look as well. Also, look for the Godzilla jump!! 9/10Godzilla's Revenge- Basically a collection of Godzilla's battles on monster-island, since all the fights are just repeats from other films. Great film, if you just watch the fights. But Minilla and the boy are horrible to watch. Lots of action and Godzilla kicking butt, this one isn't really worth watching if you've seen all the other one's though. I would watch Japenese to avoid the bad dubbing. 5.0 (I can't decide if the American Gojira is worse or better than this.)Terror of MechaGodzilla- The sequel to Godzilla vs. Mecha. Not as good as the first one, but still delivers some good action. Godzilla is outnumbered and both his entrances are cool, especially the first one. Godzilla's roar doesn't sound right, it seems like they're recordings of old recordings of Godzilla's roar. Titanosaurus isn't that great, but it's nice to see a new monster. I like how Mechagodzilla was taken down and the human involvment. American and Japenese version seemed pretty similiar to me. The camera angles and shots are arguably the best in the series. Last Godzilla film of the Showa series. 8/10I'm glad that Classic Media released this. You should definetely invest your money in this if your Godzilla fan. The commentary tracks on the American versions, make this set even more recommended, as they point out things, ask questions, have past interview recordings and let you learn so much more about the films and Godzilla overall. Overall the rating of all the films on average is an 8, which is really impressive. Awesome set that is 100% mandatory for fans. I wish Classic Media had the rights to all the Godzilla films. Overall, 9.5/10.

reviewText: I'd have to say this is, currently, the best collection of Godzilla classics. Each movie includes both the original Japanese film, as well as the U.S. release.Besides the original 'Godzilla' (Gojira) and it's sequel 'Godzilla Raids Again', the U.S. releases have very subtle changes. The U.S. titles are different and certain small scenes were edited in or out (but not nearly to the extent as the first two).For example: Godzilla vs. Mothra... if you choose to watch the U.S. version, the title now becomes Godzilla vs. The Thing, and the characters in the movie refer to it as The Thing and 'Modra' at times. It can be a little confusing. Besides that it's almost identical to the original film. I guess all I'm getting at is... I recommend seeing the first three in this collection as the original Japanese films with subtitles, and watching all the movies after as the dubbed U.S. versions.My minor complaint with this Godzilla collection is that it doesn't include Charge of the Monsters (Destroy All Monsters - U.S. version). All Ishiro Honda's movies are here EXCEPT Destroy All Monsters. I'm a little curious why. They included All Monsters Attack (Godzilla Revenge)... which is one of the worst Godzilla films to date, yet they left out Destroy All Monsters. Again, not a big deal, but it would have felt more complete. Other than that, it's hard to nitpick at anything. For the price, currently 24.99, it's a great deal.Ishiro Honda's original series bundled up in one collection. Any fan of Godzilla will appreciate this release. If you're any means new to Godzilla, start here! Buy it, watch a marathon, and enjoy buildings and monsters being demolished!

reviewText: Until this boxset, there has not been a better and more comprehensive collection of Godzilla movies. Several years ago, Classic Media releasedGodzilla - The Ultimate Collection (Godzilla, King of the Monsters/Godzilla vs. Mothra/Godzilla's Revenge/Terror of Mechagodzilla/Rodan). Then, to commemorate the Big-G's 50th birthday, Tri Star releasedGodzilla DVD Collection (Godzilla (1998) / Godzilla 2000 / Godzilla vs. King Ghidora / Godzilla and Mothra The Battle for Earth / Godzilla vs. Destoroyah / Godzilla vs. Space Godzilla / Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla / Giant Monsters All Out Attack / Godzil.... But those DVDs were sabotaged, either by the inappropriate aspect ratio, the lack of Japanese soundtrack or (in the case of the CM boxset) lousy picture and audio quality.Unlike TriStar, though, it seems Classic Media has learned its lesson and decided to treat Godzilla with the respect that he rightfully deserves. In 2004, the original Japanese version of "Godzilla" was released in the US for the first time, thanks to Film Forum. Not only did it earn critical acclaim but the people involved with the film such as director Ishiro Honda and special effects wizard Eiji Tsuburaya received a long overdue re-evaluation after years of having their work smeared as low-budgeted camp.It should come to no surprise to any Godzilla fan (or sci-fi fan in general) that the best Godzilla movies, as well as the better Toho science-fiction/fantasy movies, involved both Honda and/or Tsuburaya. Classic Media does both men, as well as the Godzilla fans, proud by collecting some, if not all, the best Godzilla movies involving either Honda or Tsuburaya or both. These seven movies: Godzilla (1954); Godzilla Raids Again (1955); Mothra vs. Godzilla (1964); Ghidorah, the Three-Headed Monster (1964); Invasion of Astro-Monster (1965); All Monsters Attack (1969); and Terror of Mechagodzilla (1975) are all packaged in one glorious boxset with both the English dubbed and original Japanese versions, as well as bonus features such as audio commentaries, trailers and brief featurettes on the series' main creators: Honda, Tsuburaya, composer Akira Ifukube, producer Tomoyuki Tanaka, the suit actors/makers and the actresses involved in these movies.1.Gojira / Godzilla, King of the MonstersREVIEW:This was the one that started it all. In 1954, producer Tomoyuki Tanaka was on his way back to Japan via flight when he looked out the window and thought about the infamous Lucky Dragon 5 incident that created mass panic due to radiation sickness inflicted on the crew and possible effects on the tuna. This incident provided the basis of the movie's premise: what if a nuclear explosion had accidentally awakened a prehistoric creature and caused him to lash out against humanity? Afterwards, Tanaka hired director Honda, SFX wizard Tsuburaya and composer Ifukube to create what eventually became "Godzilla". Using his experience in WWII as a catalyst, Honda made the movie's anti-nuclear theme even more palpable by making Godzilla's destruction of Tokyo a metaphor of the Hiroshima/Nagasaki bombings.This was the version that was finally shown in US for the first time in 2004. Many people who saw the Raymond Burr version were stunned by the original's melancholic feel, its overpowering sadness, sense of horror and provocative politics that never would have seen the light of day in America back in the 50's. Beforehand, American distributors released a more revised version featuring Burr to make it in tune with the 50's monster-on-the-loose movies like The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms, Them! and 20 Million Miles to Earth. Ironically, it made the monster more popular than the original did, but the anti-nuclear theme and scenes involving the H-Bomb, Nagasaki and Hiroshima were either deleted, subdued or neutered. But now, both versions can finally be seen in America and decided upon which is better. It shouldn't surprise anyone that the original Japanese cut is infinitely superior but the Americanized version deserves a lot of credit for bringing Godzilla to the Western masses. What makes this a DVD a fine is that both versions are presented here.BONUS EXTRAS:In addition to containing both versions of "Godzilla", the DVD contains a wealth of bonus extras, although most of it is found on the first disc. The first disc contains two 13 minute shorts: one on how the story behind the film was made and the other on the trial-and-error process of making and moving within a Godzilla suit. There's also trailers for both versions as well. But the greatest bonus feature is the audio commentary by Steve Ryfle and Ed Godziszewski, which provides fascinating detail on how and why the movie was made, what happened during the making of the movie and the movie's release, as well as how the American version of "Godzilla" came to be. These two truly show love for "Godzilla" and their love comes through in their endlessly enjoyable commentaries.2.Godzilla Raids AgainREVIEW:Out of all the Godzilla sequels, this is easily the most overlooked. Released in a mere six-seven months after the original "Godzilla", "Godzilla Raids Again" pits the Big-G (in a slimmer, uglier-looking suit) against Anguirus, a dinosaur who looks like a cross between an Ankylosaurus and a Ceratosaurus, in Osaka. To cash in on the original, Toho brought back Tsuburaya and Tanaka but not Honda and Ifukube and their presence is clearly missed. Without Honda's human drama, the characters come across looking cardboard and uninteresting. And Masaru Sato's score lacks the dread and emotional grandeur of Ifukube's work. Ironically, Sato later did fine scores on a couple of Godzilla sequels such as "Son of Godzilla" and "Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla". That being said, "Godzilla Raids Again" has a lot to recommend: Sato's score in scenes with Godzilla first arriving in Osaka is effectively chilly; the monster fights are brutal and exciting; and the final battle between Godzilla and a fleet of planes on a mountain-bound island is masterfully directed. So for a cash-in, it's not bad.But regardless of what you think of the original, it is a masterpiece compared to its American version "Gigantis, the Fire Monster". When "Godzilla Raids Again" was brought to US in 1959, it received a radically altered treatment like the original "Godzilla". Unlike the original, though, the American version of "Godzilla Raids Again" bombed. Why? Whereas the US version of "Godzilla" was still very respect to the original, "Gigantis" is downright insulting not only to the original Japanese version but to moviegoers who have a brain and a capacity to think. Stock footage, narration that never stops, mismatched roars, inappropriate stock music, cringe-inducing translations and an infamous dubbed line ("Banana oil") makes this more of a worthy viewing for midnight audiences than serious monster fans.EXTRAS:Not only does this disc contain both the hideously bad US version and the flawed but still entertaining Japanese cut for the first time but it also contains a 13-minute short involving the suitmation on numerous Toho monster movies and an amusingly entertaining audio commentary by Steve Ryfle and his friends on the US version. It's no MST3K but it'll do and it certainly makes an intolerably bad cut even more enjoyable to watch.3.Mothra vs. GodzillaREVIEW:Now we're getting somewhere. Widely regarded as the greatest of all Godzilla sequels, "Mothra vs. Godzilla" is a shining example on how to make an entertaining monster movie. Made by the four original creators of "Godzilla", "MvG" boasts a terrific music score, great acting, entertaining human villains, spectacular special effects, underlining satire on consumerism and greed and one of the greatest Godzilla suits of all time. Godzilla has never looked more menacing and his first appearance, when emerges from underground, is a stunner. And despite being a prop, Mothra looks so animated that the 8-year old in me honestly thought that this was an actual living creature with butterfly wings."MvG" also has the privilege of containing honest-to-God good English dubbing. Unlike the horrendous Americanized treatment of "Godzilla Raids Again", the English version here is not only very respectful but also contains a deleted scene not shown in Japan: a scene where the US battle cruisers attack Godzilla while he is walking along the beach. This is a special treat for American viewers as the scene is exciting to watch.EXTRAS:"MvG" contains a couple of minor but vastly entertaining bonus features. The first is a featurette on composer Akira Ifukube and the second is the ever-insightful audio commentary by Ryfle and Godziszewski for the US version. As usual, these two know their stuff and they clearly express their love for "MvG" as an epitome of everything good about Toho science-fiction cinema.4.Ghidorah, The Three-Headed MonsterREVIEW:One of my all-time favorite entries of the original Godzilla series, released for the first time in both the Japanese and English version on DVD. This was the movie that made me a life-long Godzilla fan. It marked the introduction of Godzilla's arch-enemy: the three-headed dragon Ghidorah and was a turning point in the series, where Godzilla was no longer an imminent force of destruction but a reluctant anti-hero forced to defend his home turf against outsiders. Eventually, he would become a children's hero but we're still five or six years away from that. Right now, let's celebrate the Big-G in his all-monster mayhem glory."Ghidorah, the Three-Headed Monster" was released months after "Mothra vs. Godzilla" and the rushness of the production shows: Godzilla doesn't use his radioactive breath that much; the fights between Godzilla and Rodan look silly; and the storyline is all over the place, so it may be confusing to moviegoers with short attention spans. But for many monster fans, this movie is pure nirvana. Filled with a complicated but exciting James Bond-style story involving the assassination plot of an Asian country princess, great pacing, a fantastic destruction scene by Ghidorah on Tokyo and a four-monster battle that is flat-out epic in visual scope, "Ghidorah" is a must-have for many Godzilla fans.EXTRAS:Like "MvG" beforehand, "Ghidorah" contains a featurette, a trailer and an audio commentary as bonus features. Unlike "MvG", though, the audio commentary here by David Kalat is a major disappointment. While he is undeniably informative, Kalat's hurried and irritating way of explaining his points is a step down from the audio commentaries in the three previous Godzilla movies. On the other hand, the featurette on SFX man Eiji Tsuburaya is well-done and informative, without being overly long-winded.5.Invasion of Astro-MonsterREVIEW:Along with "MvG" and "Ghidorah", "Invasion of Astro Monster" marks the apex of the golden age of Japanese science-fiction cinema. "Astro Monster" (released in US as "Monster Zero") marks the first in all Godzilla sequels where alien invasion and monster control became integral to the storytelling and it's also one of the rare Godzilla sequels where the human characters steal the picture from the monsters. Indeed, the monsters (even Godzilla) are pushed to the side and the emphasis is more on human drama and art direction than monster destruction.Some kaiju fans may find this to tough to enjoy, especially compared to the quick pacing of "Ghidorah". But it is also a welcoming change to a series that was starting to tread water. It also provides a showcase for Honda, presenting his skills as a competent director of actors than a creator of monster carnage. For me, the best way to approach "Astro Monster" is if you can regard it as a spiritual successor to "The Mysterians" and "Battle in Outer Space", two other Toho science-fiction movies that also dealt with themes of alien invasion, monster control and a plea for world cooperation against a common disaster.EXTRAS:Like the previous four discs, "Astro Monster" contains a featurette, a trailer and an audio commentary. Like "Ghidorah", the audio commentary, this time by Stuart Galbraith IV, is frustratingly uneven. If Kalat was too frantic and hurried, then Galbraith IV is too slow and measured. The featurette, on producer Tomoyuki Tanaka, is another solid effort, though.6.All Monsters AttackREVIEW:Ooh, boy.Ask any Godzilla fan what their least favorite entry of the original series is and chances are they'll say "All Monsters Attack" (released in the US as "Godzilla's Revenge"). Ask them why and they'll state the following: there's too much stock footage; it contains Minilla; and Gabara is one of the dumbest-looking foes Godzilla has ever faced. But the main reason of their disdain for "Attack" is that the movie was promoted as a children's film.While I agree with some of these assessments, that this movie should be reviled because it was promoted as a children's film is unfair and needs a counterargument. At the time of "Attack"'s release, the Japanese film industry was in a huge upheaval and monster movies (even "Godzilla" sequels) were becoming increasingly geared toward child audiences. Rather you thought it was a good move by Toho to make Godzilla more child-friendly is highly debatable; but as a children's movie, which this movie was marketed as, it does its job. "Attack" is nowhere near as good as all the sequels above but it fulfills expectations as a children's movie. Of course, adults are going to hate this movie but it wasn't made for them; it was made for kids under 8. And in that sense, "Attack" succeeds where worse movies like "Godzilla vs. Hedorah" fail: it is fun, harmless and inoffensive; nothing more, nothing less.EXTRAS:Like the previous five discs, "Attack" contains a featurette and an audio commentary. However, it's missing a trailer. The featurette on Ishiro Honda is short and sweet but it seems out of place on a widely despised Godzilla movie. The audio commentary by Richard Pusateri is a huge improvement over the previous two commentaries, but still nowhere in the league as Ryfle and Godziszewski.7.Terror of MechagodzillaThe final movie of the set and the final Godzilla movie of the original series, "Terror of Mechagodzilla" unites Honda and Ifukube and brings the Godzilla series back to its destructive roots. That's not to say that Godzilla is now a bad guy but compared to subpar works like "Gigan", "Megalon" and "Hedorah", "Terror" is a return to form for the King of the Monsters. This time, Godzilla is pitted against his cyborg counterpart Mechagodzilla and the amphibian beast Titanosaurus, both under control by space alien invaders."Terror" may have been a return to form for the Big-G but that doesn't mean it is in the same league as "MvG", "Ghidorah" and "Astro Monster". "Terror" suffers from uneven acting, sluggish pacing and sloppy editing. On the other hand, Ifukube's somber music, the entertaining monster fights, a fiercer-looking Mechagodzilla suit, Mechagodzilla's destruction of Tokyo and a compelling tragic heroine compensates for the movie's flaws. It also helps that this movie features one of my all-time favorite Godzilla entrances of the entire series. Still, these were not enough to save the Big-G as it was the lowest-attended Godzilla movie of all time and the series was put to rest for nearly 9 years.EXTRAS:Like "All Monsters Attack", "Terror" contains a featurette and an audio commentary but no trailer. The commentary by Keith Aiken and Bob Johnson is insightful, matter-of-fact and enjoyable to listen to. This time, the featurette focuses on the female actors of Toho monster movies.OVERALL:There are many other Godzilla installments out there, some more popular and others more expensive but the heart of the series lies in these seven movies (or six, if you really hate "Attack" that badly). Watching these seven movies is like seeing the evolution of a beloved monster icon: from manifestation of a nuclear bomb ("Godzilla", "Godzilla Raids Again") and force of nature ("Mothra vs. Godzilla", first half of "Ghidorah") to reluctant defender of Earth (second half of "Ghidorah", "Monster Zero") and children's hero ("All Monsters Attack") and back to his role as a gritty antihero ("Terror of Mechagodzilla"). These are not only extremely entertaining movies; they are an account of the monster's career in the 50's-70's.To have all these movies collected in one DVD set and for a low price is a dream come true for all Toho monster fans. I cannot recommend this box set enough to anybody into Godzilla. It may well be the only Godzilla box set you need.Strongest recommendation.P.S. And if you're that much of a Godzilla completest, I'd also recommendDestroy All Monsters, which was just released by Media Blasters.

reviewText: The James Bond series of movies has been going for almost fifty years, but even if it has brought in more dollars, it is not the longest continuing series.  That title, I believe, would go to Godzilla.  The Godzilla Collection has seven titles from the first decades of the series, all of which get some nice treatment.First is the original movie.  For most Americans - including myself, prior to getting this set - this means Godzilla, King of Monsters.  This version took the original Japanese version, dubbed it and spliced in new scenes with Raymond Burr.  It's a good enough giant monster movie, but still a pale comparison to the Japanese version, Gojira.  Gojira is a darker movie with a much clearer anti-nuclear weapon message and is, in my opinion, the second best giant monster movie ever, behind the original King Kong.  (Sadly, King Kong vs. Godzilla is missing from this set.)All the other movies also have both the original Japanese and the edited English language version, with the former almost always being superior.  This is evident with the first sequel, Godzilla Raids Again.  The American version ignores the first movie and names the monster Gigantis, no doubt causing confusion to fans of the first film.  This movie also has the first monster to fight Godzilla, Anguirus, setting a template for almost all future movies which would have monster on monster action.Godzilla vs. Mothra features the first match-up between the pair, with the benevolent Mothra trying to save Japan from the menacing Godzilla.  The American title for this one was Godzilla vs. the Thing, which may have led some people to think that the rival monster would be the James Arness villain from the classic sci-fi movie.The next movie in the set marks a turning point for Godzilla, changing him from a menace to a protector of Earth.  In Ghidorah, the Three-Headed Monster, a lightning-breathed alien hydra threatens the planet and it's up to Godzilla, Rodan and Mothra to come to the rescue.  The battle resumes (minus Mothra) in Invasion of Astro Monster (aka Godzilla vs. Monster Zero).Next is, by far, the weakest in the set, All Montsters Attack (aka Godzilla's Revenge) which features a slew of monsters including the son of Godzilla, Minilla.  The story is essentially the fantasy of a boy tormented by bullies, with the kid learning lessons from Minilla (and ironically becoming a bit of a bully himself).  This is the first Godzilla movie to have a kid as the hero, but even though many of these movies are designed to appeal to children, this one aims for an even younger audience.  Both dumb and with a character (Minilla) who is almost as annoying as Jar Jar Binks, this one is for Godzilla completists only.A major step up is Terror of Mechagodzilla, the final movie in the first Godzilla cycle and the last one directed by Ishiro Honda (who directed many of the early movies, including Gojira).  This one has Godzilla fighting his robot twin for the second time, with the additional challenge of Titanosaurus and some evil aliens.This set is a good sampling of the first cycle of Godzilla movies, which ran from the mid-fifties to the mid-seventies.  There would be two more cycles running up to the middle of the last decade. Overall, this is a wonderful set, with two versions of each movie, commentaries for all movies (two for the first one), some biographies, trailers, poster galleries and mini-documentaries.  Outside of Gojira, I'd be hard pressed to call any of these movies classics, but they're still fun and for fans of Japanese monster movies, this is a must-own.

reviewText: The Godzilla Collection is essential for old fans of the king of the monsters and the best possible introduction for the uninitiated. Adults will love the informative special features and the unedited, subtitled original versions of the films (including the dark, metaphor laden original Gojira) and the kids will love the monster mash spectacle of the US versions of the films.This set includes:Gojira/Godzilla King of the MonstersThe original Japanese version is an ominous anti-nuclear parable released only a few years after Hiroshima and Nagasaki. It's quite different from the series it spawned and a rather remarkable film (Akira Kurosawa rated it as one of his 100 fav films!). The US version adds scenes of Raymond Burr and turns it into a more traditional '50s monster on the loose flick, making it more of a romp but still retaining some of the somber tone.Godzilla Raids AgainDespite the cool title this flick dissapoints: a quicky sequel to the original, rushed into production and featuring little of the crew that made the first film special. The US version, also included, is downright bizzare and adds a bit of (unintential)comedy to lighten things up. Still, there is some neat monster footage of Godzilla and the new monster, Angilas. The only other black and white film in the series.Mothra vs. GodzillaThe greatest of all Godzilla sequels. The monster suits and puppets, the model sets, the animated death rays and electric bolts, and the compositing of special effects footage into "real" footage are all top notch and the work of master craftsmen in their peak. The wonderfully direct story features duel plots of Godzilla's reappearance in Japan and the discovery and acquisition of island god Mothra's egg by crooked businessmen is executed very well.Ghidorah, The Three Headed MonsterFun abounds in the incresingly comic book-y sequel which pits Godzilla, Mothra, and now Rodan against the cosmic doombringer: Ghidorah! This freewhelming film features a James Bond inspired plot with the human cast fighting foreign bad guys while the fate of the world is determined by the men-in-suit monsters cast.Invasion of Astro MonsterA personal fav of mine, this is actually a really cool alien invasion flick with the monsters used mainly as a plot device (weapons of the aliens). Second tier Hollywood star Nick Adams is the star and he delivers and wonderfully hammy performance along with an incredibly likeable cast of other characters who inhabit this galexy-trotting adventure.All Monsters AttackThe much hated but really not that bad flick in which the monsters are fictional, merely fetured in the dream sequences of the young boy who is the star. It's understandable why it's such a divisive film, but viewed on its own as a children's film it's not bad.Terror of MechagodzillaWe jump ahead to the mid-'70s for the last film in the original run of Godzilla films. This film lacks the quality of the earlier films (massive cuts in time and budget due to economic factors in Japan), but is a fitting send-off to the series, featuring Godzilla (by now a superhero character and not the violent monster of earlier films) battling his robot double and a mind-controlled dinosaur.

reviewText: As a HUGE fan of the Godzilla series since I could form Cohesive sentences and thought, this set is probably the best fan service any Godzilla fan could ask for. Classic Media has done these movies a huge justice for the American kaiju movie market. The set includes a 2-disk set that includes both Godzilla, king of the monsters, and the original and unabridged Japanese GOJIRA. Also included are Godzilla raids again(AKA Gigantis the fire monster), Mothra versus Godzilla(AKA Godzilla vs The Thing), Ghidorah The Three-Headed Monster, Invasion of Astro(AKA Godzilla vs Monster Zero), All Monsters Attack(AKA Godzilla's Revenge), And Terror of Mechagodzilla. Each DVD comes with both the original English Dub and the Original Japanese versions, as well as extras about the original crew behind the creation of our favorite titan of terror, and about how Godzilla came about. Classic Media should be supported so that it might be possible in the future for them to gain the rights to other Godzilla movies owned by Sony and Godzilla Vs Biollante, which is owned by HBO. Aside from that, this set is a must buy for any fan of the Godzilla franchise both young and old.
summary: Great set for any fan of the big G. Classic media does series great Justice

reviewText: For Godzilla completionists, this set comes as Heaven sent.Who would have thought that a company like Classic Media, small time until recently, would be able to pull off Godzilla releases that would put the big boys in the business to shame?In the set you receive 7 discs, but in some respects, 14 different films. How could that be you might ask? Well, it turns out that Classic Media compiled the set in a way that allows them to include the edited English language video and dubbed English language audio versions on the same disc with the unedited, uncensored, uncut and undoctored Japanese language and video options. This set truly does give G- fans the best of both worlds!Video quality on the discs is very good. I believe the video was taken from the Japanese remasters done for the DVD releases in 2006 (I believe they were done in 2006) as was the audio.Audio quality, for the most part, is very good as well. On Godzilla and Godzilla Raids Again discs, in the silent areas of the film, you can hear quite audible hiss. This isn't so bad on regular TV speakers, but with a proper AV receiver and speakers it can be a little distracting.The extras are pretty nice as well. Generally every disc has a short featurette about say, suit acting, the music or so on. The Godzilla releaseGojira / Godzilla, King of the Monstersis the same as the single DVD release, including the booklet.This is a great release that any Godzilla fan should have in their collection. Hopefully Classic Media sees fit to rescue the horrible releases done by TriStar/Columbia with the Godzilla vs King Ghidorah/Godzilla & Mothra: Battle for Earth and the Godzilla vs Space Godzilla/Godzilla vs Destroyah 2 packs and give us proper editions of those fine films as well.Highly recommended to any Godzilla fan.
